Nearly six years ago, our community changed forever when 19 people were shot as Representative Giffords met with her constituents. This attack on our democracy resulted in six deaths, including the first assassination of a congressional staffer, Gabe Zimmerman, in the line of duty. While the pain and grief for those we lost will always be with us, we also remember how Tucson came together to show courage, compassion, and unity.   On Friday, I will introduce a bill along with Senators McCain and Flake to designate the January 8th Memorial in Tucson a permanent national memorial. Our community’s response in the face of this tragedy stood as an example of love for the entire country, and in designating this memorial, we move one step closer to permanently enshrining that spirit and the memory of those killed.

Today, I led the U.S. House in a moment of silence in honor of the January 8, 2011 shooting victims. My thanks to my colleagues from Arizona and around the country for joining me to commemorate their memories and how our community came together following this tragedy.

Women Airforce Service Pilots (WASPs) were a group of less than 1,100 women who flew non-combat missions during World War II. One of these heroes, Marty Wyall, passed away on the evening of March 9. Marty Wyall was a pioneer who paved the way for pilots like me and all women to serve in uniform, and we owe her a debt of gratitude. I was honored to meet this fearless woman last fall at Arlington Cemetery during the historic funeral for fellow WASP Elaine Harmon. My thoughts and prayers are with her family during this time—her children and grandchildren. Please join me in honoring her life and her legacy.

Yesterday the U.S. Air Force testified that it is considering retiring one of the best air-to-air combat jets in our inventory, replacing the F-15Cs and F-15Ds with F-16s.  The Air Force had not told anyone about these proposed changes until the hearing yesterday.  As with the A-10, the F-15 brings a unique set of capabilities that isn’t replaced by a jack-of-all-trades like the F-16.  Even with radar upgrades, I’m not convinced this is the best approach—we're already in a readiness crisis. I will continue to examine the Air Force’s plan to ensure continued US air superiority.

The House swiftly and decisively took action to crack down on non-consensual pornography in the military by voting for my bill, the PRIVATE Act. This March it was discovered that members of the military were posting nude, intimate photos of women as well as personal information, such as their names and duty stations, without their consent or knowledge. This is degrading and has no place in our military.  My bill will define when private photo sharing is a military criminal act—which is not clear in current law, giving the military a sharper tool to prosecute these perpetrators.   The measure—introduced just last month, has broad bipartisan support with over 100 cosponsors and passed today on a vote of 418-0.   Learn more: https://goo.gl/qf2Rkg

81 days after the Marines United scandal broke, the House passed my bill to define this as a military crime.   The vote of passage was 418-0.   I commend the House for swiftly and decisively taking action to give the military tools to crack down on this problem.

Our service members should not have to watch their backs among the individuals who are supposed to be their teammates.   I'm thankful that the House passed my bill to clean this up with overwhelming bipartisan support and 100+ cosponsors. By clarifying when private photo sharing is a military criminal act, the PRIVATE Act gives the military the tools to prosecute the perpetrators.

After a year and a half long battle with head and neck cancer, Phil Ledford's spirit left his earthly vessel to be united with God earlier today at the VA hospital in Tucson.   He was surrounded by loved ones over these last days--both human and furry.  I was privileged to share Phil's journey for the last 20 years as next door neighbors, and having lost my dad at 12, he was like a father to me. Phil was a rare treasure to those of us who were blessed to know and love him. He was selfless, literally until his last breath, always thinking of serving and protecting others.  He proudly served our country in the Navy for four years and continued to tell stories of his time in uniform many decades later with a smile and a glimmer in his eye. He worked hard his whole life with his hands, and loved to fix things and take care of things for others. Phil was a dog-lover, including his own furry angels like his beloved English setter Molly, many foster rescue golden retrievers, and my two goldens--Penelope and now Boomer. We have a hole in the wall between our houses so the dogs could roam freely in our little "commune," sometimes scoring two dinners before we could coordinate on text.     Phil and his wife Helene were married for 41 years, a wonderful example of faithful devotion and partnership.  Helene has been an amazing wingwoman in this very difficult fight with cancer as a caregiver and partner while balancing work and other responsibilities she had to take on due to Phil's illness.  Phil's endearing, curmudgeonly personality would make for some lively discussions on a variety of topics, but his stubbornness helped him in the grueling struggle with cancer and treatment. In these last days, he was truly suffering in pain from this aggressive carcinoma, and his body started to shutdown. Today we were praying over him affirming he could let go and be with God fully restored and freed from all memories of the suffering. In the midst of our prayer, he squeezed his eyes closed two times, then took his last breath. We are relieved he isn't in pain anymore, but heart-broken missing him and his presence in our lives. Rest well, Phil, and know that you are deeply loved and missed. Thanks to so many who have been praying for Phil all along and in these last days. I am deeply grateful.  With all the negative focus on the VA, I also want to pass on my heartfelt gratitude to the amazing men and women who cared for Phil during this complex path of surgeries, treatment, recovery, setbacks, multiple scares, and  ultimately hospice.  I want to specifically thank Dr. Steve Thomson and Dr. Michael Bays, who exhibited extraordinary skill, commitment, expertise, counsel, and compassion on this roller coaster ride. ENT PA Guy Penn did an exceptional job helping to treat the many wounds Phil experienced along the way. And I am deeply thankful for all the nurses who cared for him 24/7 during multiple stays and especially in these last weeks.  Special thanks to Jackie Gudanowski, Tracy Johnston, Chris Gates, Armeda Valenzuela, and Sheree Booth. You are all truly angels in our midst with a special gift for caring and compassion.  You allowed Phil to fight with all possible weapons and bravely depart this world with dignity and peace.

Each of us remembers that terrible day 16 years ago. At the time, I was 10 months into a year-long deployment to Saudi Arabia. Like most Americans, I first learned of the attacks from watching the news, as real-time images of planes striking the twin towers streamed across TVs in the Air Operations Center. Initially, there was a lot of confusion and disbelief. Very quickly, though, it became clear — we were under attack.  For me and those around me in uniform, we were outraged that our cowardly enemies would choose to attack innocent civilians instead of bringing the fight to us, those who signed up to serve. But our feelings of anger swiftly gave way to a hardened resolve to bring to justice those responsible and win this war on terror, militarily and ideologically.  It wasn’t long before orders came in that we would be taking military action in Afghanistan, and our role was to plan, execute, and provide oversight of the air campaign. The next few months were some of the most stressful and sleepless days and nights of my life as we went after Al Qaeda and the Taliban government that gave them refuge.  Today, the name of our enemy has changed, but their hateful ideology has not. ISIS still promotes the same intolerant, violent, extremist ideology that Al Qaeda did previously.   In the face of these evolving and dangerous threats, we must remain vigilant. In my roles on two critical national security committees, the House Armed Services Committee and the Homeland Security Committee, I am committed to ensuring our military is strong and that we have robust security systems in place.  Above all, we must remember it is the ideals at the core of our nation that will ultimately win out over radical Islamic extremism: freedom, opportunity, and equal treatment for all.  By holding true to our core American values, we can ensure a more safe and prosperous future for our country.

This morning the Supreme Court heard oral arguments on Masterpiece Cakeshop v. Colorado Civil Rights Commission.   Equal rights and freedom of speech/religion can and should co-exist in our country and all are protected by the Constitution.  However, in recent years, there has been an attempt to protect the former while infringing on the rights of the latter.   Unlike other businesses aiming to levy blanket discrimination, Jack Phillips serves everyone in his cake-shop regardless of who they are or who they love, including pre-made cakes for any event.  Phillips simply asked that he not be forced by the government to use his artistic talents to design custom cakes that express beliefs that violate his sincerely-held religious views. That's a crucial distinction. This is a very narrow request for freedom of speech and religious liberty.  Today’s case is not about discrimination—it’s about whether or not the government should be able to compel artists to create things that clash with their faith.  Although Phillips asked for a very narrow exception, Colorado ordered him to create the custom cake against his conscience. To honor his beliefs, he stopped designing all custom cakes and workers lost jobs since that was 40% of his small business.  Yet Colorado’s public accommodation law has not been neutrally applied in all circumstances, instead, it is forcing compliance for specific ideological issues.   The outcome of Phillip’s case before the Supreme Court will have wide-ranging impact. America needs to preserve our tradition that allows people of good faith to disagree and find ways for all of our constitutional rights to remain protected.
